title: Georgia House - Day 11 (2026-02-03)
summary:
Here is a structured markdown summary of the Georgia House - Day 11 (2026-02-03) session:

**Overview**
The session featured a moving tribute and background information on Representative Wayne Scott Gayard, as well as a passionate speech by Representative Carl Henderson emphasizing the importance of blessing and serving God.

**Bills Introduced (First Reading)**
No new bills were introduced.

**Notable Moments**
- Representative Henderson highlighted Representative Gayard's impressive background, including his work as a pastor, founder of Savannah Feed the Hungry, filmmaker, and devoted family man.
- Representative Henderson delivered a rousing speech calling on legislators to praise and serve God, emphasizing the importance of having a relationship with God and doing "reasonable service" to bless others.

**Votes**
No recorded votes.

**Attendance**
Quorum was present.

**Adjournment**
The session adjourned. The next session is scheduled for [next session date].

Thank you, Mr. Speaker, and I appreciate everyone's commitment to access to quality health care. I know we're working on mental health care, but it's something I know the speaker, and this whole body has been committed to for many years now, access to quality health care, including the first chairman of our committee, Chairman Smith. Thank you for the opportunity. Access to quality health care is all of us know involves not only having the hospitals, the doctors, and the pharmacies that you need available, but it depends on having a health plan that helps make them affordable for a patient. We have an opportunity today to advance affordability for patients in a small but often significant way. That is addressing the patient's out-of-pocket costs for prescription medications at the point of sale. So to understand HB-867 and how it lowers costs for patients, I do have to briefly review the complex process that's developed that determines how a patient's out-of-pocket costs is calculated. PBMs have the role in setting the price both to the health insurance plan as well as the patient's out-of-pocket costs at the point of sale. PBMs are very large corporations, and as a matter of fact, the top three PBMs, only three control access to medication and the costs for over 80% of Americans. So these are large organizations. So what do they do? They agree on a list price for the medication from the manufacturer. They determine which drugs, especially newer brand-named drugs, are even on-formulary, which means they're covered by your insurance or not. Their software determines what price the patient will pay at the counter of any pharmacy whether an independent or chain or anything else at the counter. One final thing the PBMs do is they also negotiate with the manufacturer a very carefully protected, even secret rebate from the list price that's paid directly from the drug manufacturer to the PBM. Some of the newer medications that are out there, and we all see them on television, and there's hundreds of others, and we hope for those of us with chronic conditions that there'll be more and more that make lives better in the future. So on these newer medications, sometimes the rebate could be 20%, 30%, even 60% are higher once again paid directly from the manufacturer of the drug to the PBM. As I said, these are very large and powerful corporations. HBA 67 simply requires that the PBM, when calculating the patients out of pocket cost, that the PBM used the true net price, which is described in the bill. The true net price is just that list price I've mentioned, minus any rebates that are received. So as an example, and I said, these are newer advanced drugs, some of it make a vital difference for patients' life, sometimes keeping them off of disability, sometimes even saving their lives. So let's use an example real quick, which is a new medication that's very valuable and it's a thousand dollar list price. Currently, a patient, if they're in the 20% copay portion of their insurance, would obviously have to pay $200. However, if that drug, a thousand dollar drug has a $600 rebate, if we pass in its signed HBA 67, they'd only be paying 20% of $400 or $80. So you've got $200 or $80 out of pocket. Obviously, if you're still in the deductible period of your insurance, which more and more of us might be, for pharmaceutical benefits, it might be the difference between $400 and $1,000 out of pocket. So as you can say, this can have a massive effect on what the out of pocket cost can be. So four things about what this bill does not do. It's not meant to solve every problem. Number one, it doesn't change plan design. The patient still has to pay 20% of that true net cost, and believe me, that's far more than what a generic would be. So there's still a strong incentive to, when it's appropriate with your doctor to use a generic medication, that's much more affordable. Number two, it doesn't benefit pharmacies or pharmacists in any way financially. There are things that PBMs do with pharmacies and pharmacists that are very challenging, let's say. This doesn't benefit them financially in any way. However, pharmacists are strongly in support of this bill. They are the ones. They're the last one between someone being ill, going to their doctor, deciding on a prescription, taking it and then finding out the price. They're the last one there to counsel the patient on how to take the medication. The importance of taking the medication as prescribed. And so they know that if it's a high copay or high deductible, they're much less likely to get the patient. So they care about affordability and compliance. Number three, HB-867 doesn't really ban the process of paying rebates. That's really outside our scope here in Georgia. It's a difficult thing to do nationally. Some of these are international pharmaceutical companies and PBMs that buy medications from all over. So we don't ban the process. All we do is make sure that the patient receives the benefit. So finally, HB-867 does not raise premiums, which some have accused it of doing. We've corrected this by, you'll notice at the end of the bill, where if there's a PBM that passes through 100% of the rebates to the planned sponsor, whether the insurer or the employer, if they're passing through 100% of the rebates, especially if these are audited, and that planned sponsor decides to lower everyone's premiums equally, then we don't, we don't require, that this bill doesn't affect them. So those plans that exist like that, and with some PBMs, large percentage of their plans are done that way. So this won't affect them at all. It won't cause them to have to raise premiums on everybody so that they can give a benefit to some. So this bill doesn't try to correct that. Finally, there are indications that HB-867 may even lower premiums. From the PBMs own material, and I have one from one of the largest out there, when patients have more affordable prescriptions, lower copays, lower cost at the point of sale, PBMs recognize that they're more likely to get their medicines. They're more likely to take their medications and not stretch them out to maybe every other day for a daily medicine or cutting pills in half or other things, sometimes only picking up half of a prescription. That's what the pharmacists see. When they do comply with the doctor and the pharmacist's recommendation, well, guess what happens? They're less likely to have complications. Anybody knows one of the big complications for hypertension is a renal failure. Well, obviously, medications taken properly can help avoid someone going into renal failure and the expense on a life that that can be. So they're less likely to have complications, less likely to end up in the hospital, less likely to end up in an expensive emergency room. Taking patients out of the middle of what are often complex challenges in healthcare has been a strong desire and goal of this body. There's been great progress. I know with Chairman Harkins, House Bill 888, Surprise Medical Building, legislation was signed into law that when it came to Surprise Medical Bills, we took patients out of the middle. Before I begin my remarks, I would like to direct your attention to the local redistricting map at issue, which members of this body have apparently found so offensive that it has warranted unprecedented legislative action that undermines the integrity of house proceedings. Accordingly, I rise to strongly urge each member of this House to vote no to the Committee Substitute for House Bill 873 for the following reasons. First, the Wunette Legislative Delegation and the Wunette Board of Commissioners conducted a fair process, one that was transparent, inclusive, and legally compliant in every way to produce a fair map, one that abides by traditional principles of redistricting, reflects the priorities of Wunette voters, and complies with all applicable federal and state law. A no vote to this use or patient of local control would demonstrate allegiance to the principle of local control and home rule, which ensures the American people that we the people remain sovereign and have the freedom to govern ourselves as it should be in our democratic republic. Lastly, as it is not yet too late, I urge members of this House to vote no to protect the integrity of House proceedings.
